校訂文全体凡例
・ 原則として土本（以下、略称は「主要写本・版本・刊本等略称・底本一覧」参照）を底本とし、九本・剛本・条本・花本等の古写本や近本・壬本・京博本等の写本によって対校しました（巻によって使用した対校本は異なります）。
・ 条文番号・条文名称は原則として訳注本に拠りましたが、一部を修正しています（※下記「条文名称修正一覧」参照）。なお1条が長い場合など、必要に応じ「項」に分割して示すこととしました。
・ 校異は原則として底本の文字を改変する場合、あるいは写本間に参考とすべき異同がある場合、参考とすべき傍書等がある場合に付すこととしました。必ずしもその校異に関する写本をすべて網羅することはせず、主要写本のみを取り上げています。ただし訳注本と校訂文に異同が生じた場合には、できる限り校異にて言及するよう心がけました（単なる字体の相違については省略しています）。
・ 校訂文は『延喜式』撰上当初の姿の復元を目標としています。標注や傍書は、条文名称に関わるものは省略し、中世以前にさかのぼることが想定されるものに限って、校異注で言及することとしました。ただし標注のうち「弘」「貞」「延」等については便宜を考え、鉤括弧で括って校訂本文に掲げることとしました。
・ 字体は常用漢字体を原則としました。「大」と「太」、「座」と「坐」、「絇」と「約」、「績」と「續（続）」、「色」と「包」、「細」と「紬」、「鈍」と「純」、「冑」と「胃」、「絁」と「絶」、草冠と竹冠、木偏と手偏等、容易に判定される誤字や誤用・通用については、校異を省略して適宜置き換える場合があります。ただし巻9・10においては「大」「太」の差異も校異にて触れることとしました。
・ 校訂文中の細字・割書は、〈 〉で括って表現することとしました。
・ 本文に誤字・脱字等が想定される場合であっても、置き換えるべき文字や補うべき文字が明確でない場合は、校異注での言及にとどめた場合があります。
・ ユニコードにて表示されない漢字は以下のように示すことにしました。

div.p: ANNOTATED ENGLISH TRANSLATION OF SCROLL 37 OF THE *ENGI SHIKI/*
PROCEDURES OF THE BUREAU OF MEDICATIONS

div.note: On the royal medications of New Year's Day 〈follow this model for the royal consort.〉
div.p:
On the royal medications of New Year's Day１ 〈follow this model for the royal consort.〉
*Byakusan/*, one dose; *doshōsan/*, one dose; *toso/*, one dose; ointment for a thousand poxes and ten-thousand maladies, one dose.
For the offering of the medications prepare: three lacquered tables 〈place the powder medications [*byakusan/* and *doshōsan/*] and the ointment on one table; the *toso/* and the tripod pot on another; the sake cup on a decorated table〉 one silver *sake/* cup, one silver plate, one small white bronze bowl, four bronze sake cups, eight red-lacquered plates to collect leftovers 〈diameter eight *sun/*, store them in the Bureau〉
div.note: This ritual was held on the first three days of the new year according to the traditional East Asian lunisolar calendar. Here it is called "*ganjitsu no mikusuri/*," but it appears under slightly different names in other sources. In *Gishiki/* 儀式, for instance, it is called "*mikusuri wo kūzuru gi/* 供御薬儀." It originates in China and can be seen in numerous almanacs of seasonal events.

As a rule, names of compounded medications have been left untranslated except for those elements that can be discerned (personal names, number of ingredients, other numerical elements; see next note for an example). *Byakusan/*, which literally means "white powder," has been left untranslated as it is used as a proper noun, whereas a literal English translation would suggest an overly generic-sounding name. *Doshōsan/* is also a powdered medication.
*Byakusan/* and *doshōsan/* are concoctions of various medicinal herbs traditionally consumed on New Year's Day with *toso/*, a mix of medicinal herbs and spices steeped in *sake/*.

The "ointment for a thousand poxes and ten-thousand maladies" (*sensō manbyō kō/*) first appears as part of this rite in the *Engi shiki/* and its ingredients are unknown; it was not part of the New Year's celebrations in China. According to *Saikyūki/* 西宮記, a compendium on court ceremonial compiled in the tenth century by Minamoto no Takaakira 源高明 (914-983), it was offered to the *tennō/* on the third day and applied to his hands. See Maruyama, "Mikusuri wo kūzuru gi no seiritsu", pp. 153-4.
Passages enclosed in 〈 〉 (angle brackets) reproduce interlinear notes in the original text, where they are written in a smaller font.
div.p:
one pouch 〈length two *shaku/* and three *sun/*〉 one *ryō/* in strings for the pouch, twenty sheets of paper, and three *bu/* of mulberry bark strings.
For the preparation of the medications arrange: seven *ryō/* and three *bu/* of *ninjin/* [*Panax ginseng/*/Asian ginseng root] ; six *ryō/* and two *bu/* of *kanzō/* [*Glycyrrhiza uralensis/*/Chinese licorice root and rhizome]; three *bu/* of *keishin/* [*Cinnamomum cassia/*/Chinese cinnamon] 〈obtain them from the Royal Storehouse Bureau;〉 two *ryō/* and three *bu/* of *byakujutsu/* [*Atractylodes japonica/* rhizome]; one *ryō/* and two *bu/* of *daiō/* [*Rheum palmatum/*/Chinese rhubarb]; three *ryō/* and two *bu/* of *bushi/*; two *ryō/* and two *bu/* of *shokushō/* [*Zanthoxylum piperitum/* f. *inerme/*/sanshō peppercorn]; three *bu/* of *bōfū/* [*Saposhnikovia divaricate/*/siler root]; one *ryō/* and two *bu/* of *uzu/*; three *ryō/* of *saishin/* [*Asarum sieboldin/* dried plant]; two *bu/* of *bakkatsu/* [*Smilax china/*/China root]; one *bu/* of *kankyō/* [*Zingiber officinale/*/dried ginger root]; one *ryō/* and two *bu/* of *maō/* [*Ephedra sinica/*/Chinese ephedra stem]; three *ryō/* and one *bu/* of *kikyō/* [*Platycodon grandifloras/*/Chinese bellflower root]; one *ryō/* of *tōki/* [*Angelica acutiloba/*/Japanese angelica root]; two *ryō/* of *daigeki/* [*Euphorbia pekinensis/* root]; one *ryō/* of *shōma/* [*Astilbe thunbergia/*/Thunberg's astilbe rhizome]; one *ryō/* of *byakushi/* [*Angelica dahurica/*/Dahurian angelica root]; one *ryō/* of *shakuyaku/* [*Paeonia lactiflora/*/Chinese peony root]; one *ryō/* of *hōsō/* [aerial part of *Illicium anisatum/*/Japanese anise]; one *ryō/* of *ōgon/* [*Scutellaria baicalensis/*/Chinese skullcap root]; one *ryō/* of *dokkatsu/* [*Angelica pubescens/*/pubescent angelica root]; one *ryō/* of *jagan/* [leaves of *Potentilla anemonifolia/*]; five *ryō/* of *kijiō/* [*Rehmannia glutinosa/*/Chinese foxglove rhizome]; and twenty stalks of *gaihaku/* [*Allium macrostemon/*/long-stamen onion bulb] 〈as for all which is listed above, obtain it from the storehouse of the Bureau; 〉 four *shō/* of bitter vinegar; ten *kin/* of wild boar fat; four *shaku/* of silk sieve for the medications; two large containers; two *oribitsu/* containers; and one *koku/* of new charcoal.
div.note: Herbs, roots and other medicinal ingredients are given in the main text the following form: Japanese pronunciation [scientific name/common English name, if available]. In subsequent occurrences, as a rule only the Japanese pronunciation is used; in a small number of cases, for relatively familiar items (e.g., wheat, peach kernels), the English translation is used instead, and provide the scientific name only on the first occurrence.

*Bushi/*, *uzu/* and *ten'yū/* designate different elements or states of the same plant, *Aconitum Japonicum/*, known in Japanese as *torikabuto/* and in English as (Japanese) monkshood or aconite. While they are all derived from the root of the plant, *uzu/* designates the part of the root that is directly attached to the stem, and *bushi/* refers to the smaller roots that are attached to the main root. *Ten'yū/*, however, refers to the tuber onto which no smaller roots grow.
Part of the root that is directly attached to the stem of *Aconitum Japonicum/*.
*Oribitsu/* containers are traditionally made using bent hinoki cypress wood sheets. They possess characteristic rounded corners and are still used in Japan.
div.p:
As for the above [medications], make and prepare them according to precedent from the last third of the eleventh month to the last third of the twelfth month. As for the miscellaneous items that will be needed, inform the Ministry [of the Royal Household] on the fifteenth day of the tenth month. The Ministry will inform the Council [of State], which will issue a directive to the offices involved. [The Bureau of Medications] will receive and prepare [what is needed] within the first third of the eleventh month. As for other miscellaneous items, adjust their quantity depending on the circumstances. Supply all those involved in the production of the medications with a rank lower than the four administrative positions and higher than minor functionary with pure clothes 〈also provide each of those of a rank lower than the four administrative positions and higher than apprentice of medications with one *hiki/* and three *jō* of coarse plain silk and three *ton/* of silk floss; to the apprentices [of medications] who have yet to receive a performance evaluation and to the minor functionaries provide one *tan/* of cloth collected as tax-in-kind. 〉 Provide them with *sake/* and food for no longer than twenty-eight days.
Provide with pure clothes those who will offer the royal medications on New Year's Day: the director of the Office of Medications 〈in the case of the royal consort and the heir apparent, one vice-director of the Office of Medications each,〉 five female minor functionaries, and two female attendants. Give each one *jō/* of coarse plain silk and two *ton/* of silk floss 〈as for the color, choose in accordance with the propitious direction for the year [as divined by the Bureau of Yin and Yang]. Submit a lateral memorandum to the Bureau of Yin and Yang beforehand, wait for their response and afterwards request [the clothes]. Follow the same procedure also for the royal consort and the heir apparent.〉
div.note: The top four administrative positions (usually referred to as *shitōkan/* 四等官 in Japanese) consisted of *kami/* (head or director), *suke/* (vice-head or deputy director), *jō/* (third-level manager) and *sakan/* (fourth-level manager or secretary). The Chinese characters used to write these titles were not standardized, but in the case of bureaus (*ryō/* 寮) we see: *kami/* 頭, *suke/* 助, *jō/* 允 and *sakan/* 属. The term *kannin/* is used in this *shiki/* (and elsewhere in the *Engi shiki/*) to collectively refer to these four positions.

"Cloth collected as tax-in-kind" translates the term *chōfu/* 調布. Within the taxation system established under the *ritsuryō/* state, *chō/* generally consisted of cloth, which was called *chōfu/*. Another type of cloth exacted in lieu of corvée (unpaid labor due as tax), called *yōfu/* 庸布, appears later in this *shiki/*, e.g. in art. 29.

This can be interpreted in two ways: that the production of the medications had to be completed within 28 days; or that, regardless of the time required to complete the work, the payment of *sake/* and food would be rounded up or down to 28 days.

"Lateral memorandum" here translates *i/* 移, a term that within the *ritsuryō/* system of government designated a written communication between two government departments that were not in a direct hierarchical relationship.
div.p: On the last day of the twelfth month, in the first quarter of the time of the hare [5-7 AM], the Ministry of the Royal Household and the Bureau will proceed together outside the Ensei gate. After the Office of Inner Gatekeepers have announced them to the *tennō/*, the high-ranking officials of the Bureau, preceding the apprentices of medications and the others, will carry the table on which the medications have been placed, and will together enter the courtyard [located south of the Shishinden] and put the table down south of the ceremonial marker; after this, they will withdraw in order. After the Ministry of the Royal Household have announced them to the *tennō/*, they will again enter and leave with the table; then they will pass it on to the director of the Office of Medications. As for the *toso/*, the officials will guide the apprentices of medications and, on that same day, at the time of the horse [11 AM - 1 PM] will place it inside [the pouch] and steep it into the well; have officials from the Office of Water Management guard it. On New Year's Day, in the first quarter of the time of the tiger [3-5 AM], the officials will guide the apprentices of medications, approach the well and take out the medication, then a vice-director of the Ministry of the Royal Household and the officials of the Bureau will enter the yard of the royal residence carrying the medication, then proceed and place it down. Afterwards, using the silver tripod pot, they will heat up the *sake/* and steep the *toso/* [in it]. The Office of the Brewery will provide the *sake/* and the Bureau of Supplies will prepare the brazier. A vice-director of the Office of Medications will take the *sake/* cup and guide the female attendants to the designated place; he will have the young female attendants 〈chosen by the *tennō/* and courtiers〉 from the Office of Medications lick [the *toso/*] beforehand, and will then offer it to the *tennō/*. Following this, do the same with the *byakusan/* and *doshōsan/*. End this on the third day. Follow the same procedure for the royal consort and the heir apparent.
div.note: The Ensei gate was located slightly to the south on the eastern side of the royal palace complex.

This interlinear note is ambiguous; it is unclear whether the *denjō/* 殿上 that appears here refers to a person or group of people (as in the translation adopted here, where *denjō/* has been translated as "*tennō/* and courtiers") or a place (e.g., a hall) to which the female attendants had to be taken.
div.p: Afterwards, as for the payment of remunerations, give those of the fifth rank an *aoshi/*, a lined kimono worn as a jacket in winter; to the third- and forth-level managers, to the royal physician, and to the instructor women's physician give one *ren/* of silk floss each; to the minor functionaries and to the seventeen apprentices of medications, give each three *ton/* of silk floss; to the vice-director of the Office of Medications and to the six five female minor functionaries, give each five *ton/* of silk floss.

div.note: On the royal medications of the twelfth month
div.p:
On the royal medications of the twelfth month
Rhinoceros horn pellet, six doses; *shakuyaku/* [*Paeonia lactiflora/*/white peony root] pellet, three doses; *onpaku/* pellets, four doses; ointment for a thousand poxes and ten-thousand maladies, one dose; *shōma/* [*Astilbe thunbergia/*] ointment, two doses; Jīvaka's ointment, one dose; *chōchū/* pellets, two doses; *bōshō/* [mirabilite] black pellets, one dose; fermented soy bean pellets, one dose; four lacquered tables to present the medications; four small continental-style chests and four long tables to carry loads 〈all lacquered. Store them in the Bureau.〉
div.note: The term used here is *rōgetsu/* 朧月, which designates the twelfth month of the traditional East Asian lunisolar calendar. Concerning the medications produced in the twelfth month, see Maruyama, "Mikusuri wo kūzuru gi no seiritsu", pp. 154-6.

Jīvaka is the name of a legendary physician and healer who, in ancient India, became a follower of Śakyamuni Buddha. See for instance C. Pierce Salguero. "The Buddhist Medicine King in Literary Context: Reconsidering an Early Medieval Example of Indian Influence on Chinese Medicine and Surgery." *History of Religions/* 48(3), pp. 183–210.

div.note: Sue is one of the two prevalent types of pottery used in ancient Japan, the other being called Haji. Sue pottery is fired at over 1000º C and is unglazed, except for accidental glazing of surface ashes. It is gray and smooth in appearance, and was introduced to Japan by people hailing from the continent. Haji pottery is fired at lower temperatures (ca. 800-900º C) and presents a porous, reddish appearance. While originally distinct in terms of use and diffusion, by the time of the compilation of the *Engi shiki/*, both Sue and Haji had come to be used in a similarly utilitarian fashion, replaced in higher settings by glazed pottery more recently adopted from the continent.

A *tataibe/* is a large mouthed pot used primarily for storing food. Made of Haji or Sue pottery, it also appears in the documents preserved at Shōsōin, where we read that it was used to store various pickled vegetables. In *Saikyūki/*, *tataibe/* pots are used to store fish-based *hishio/* and dried fish. See Arai Hideki. "Engi Shukeishiki no doki ni tsuite (jō)," p. 70.

However, concerning the medications listed above [in this article], on the eighth day [of the first month] collect them again and send them to the place where the Gosai-e is held in the ceremonial compound of the eighth ministries; on the fourteenth day, [at the end of the rite,] return them.
div.note: Also read *Misai-e/*, this was an important Buddhist ritual carried out at court in the first month, from the eighth to the fourteenth day. Stretching over seven days, it centered around lectures on the *Konkōmyō saishōō kyō/* 金光明最勝王経 (Sutra of Golden Light. Chinese: *Jinguangming zuishengwang jing/*; Sanskrit: *Suvarṇa-prabhāsôttama-sūtra/*) by a number of eminent monks who were summoned at court for the occasion, and penitence rituals (*Kisshōten keka/* 吉祥天悔過). The Sutra of Golden Light enjoyed great popularity in East Asia, where it was considered as efficacious in protecting the state, and in promoting prosperity and good harvest in the realm. For a study in English on the Gosai-e during the Heian period, see Asuka Sango. *The Halo of Golden Light: Imperial Authority and Buddhist Ritual in Heian Japan/*. University of Hawaii Press, 2015.

three *kin/* and thirteen *ryō/* of *kengoshi/*; one *kin/* and four *ryō/* of *teirekishi/*; six *ryō/* of *rōro/*; one *kin/* and fourteen *ryō/* of animal hide gelatin; five small *to/*, one *shō/* and one *gō/* of infusion of sweet vine;
div.note: Also known as *nikawa/*, this thick gelatin was traditionally used in Japan as a gluing agent, for example in wooden Buddhist statuary. Here it is most likely used as a thickener, but according to the *Chūyaku daijiten/*, *nikawa/* also possesses medicinal properties.
div.p: five *kin/* of wild boar fat; nine *shō/* of *sake/*; two *to/* and eight *shō/* of rice vinegar; one *koku/* of glutinous rice; three *to/* of germinated rice; one *hiki/*, one *jō/* and one *shaku/* of oiled cloth; two *jō/* and two *shaku/* of coarse plain silk; eight *shaku/* of silk gauze; two *tan/*, one *jō/* and five *shaku/* of cloth collected as tax-in-kind; one *ton/* and four *ryō/* of silk floss; one large *kin/* and four *ryō/* of mulberry bark strings from Aki Province; 195 sheets of paper; fourteen jars; four *hotogi/* jars; seven *oribitsu/* containers; five large containers; half dried-gourd to be used as a ladle; one water bucket; one ladle; four *koku/* of new charcoal; 1,200 *kin/* of firewood 〈this amount also includes the firewood necessary for the production of medications for the *tennō/*.〉
div.note: *Moyashi/* 蘗 in the text. What this term designates is debated. It also appears in the context of *sake/*-making (including in the *Engi shiki/*'s section on the Office of the Brewery, or *Miki no tsukasa/* 造酒司; see below). In the *Wamyō ruiju shō/* (scroll 4 of the ten-scroll version), it appears in a section named "*kikugetsu/* 麹蘗," namely *kōji/* mold and *moyashi/*; this shows that these two substances were related but distinct. The Chinese character 糵 is glossed "*yone no moyashi/* 与禰乃毛夜之" in this text, where *yone/* means rice. The translation adopted here ("germinated rice") is based on this passage, but can also confirmed in other tenth-century sources. For instance, in the *Honzō wamyō/* 本草和名, we see that the compound 孽米, in which the character for *moyashi/* precedes the character for rice, is simply glossed "*moyashi/* 毛也之." In scroll 30 of *Ishinpō/* 医心方, we found the compound 孽米 glossed "*ine no moyashi/* 以禰乃毛也之where *ine/*, again, means rice (more specifically, the rice plant). These passages imply that the rice used here is not white rice (i.e., rice that had the germ removed), as, otherwise, there could be no germination.

*Hotogi/* were large vessels used to carry and store fluids or solids. They were characterized by a fat body and a relatively wide mouth. In the *Engi shiki/*, we see *hotogi/* both made of Sue and Haji pottery. See Arai Hideki. "Hotogi to motai ni kansuru oboegaki 瓫(盆)(ホトギ)と瓮・缶(モタイ) に関する覚え書き." *Kokuritsu rekishi minzoku hakubutsukan kenkyū hōkoku/* 218 (2019).
div.p: As for the aforesaid [medications], use the procedures illustrated above. Once the production is completed, present them on the same day as the royal medications [for the *tennō/* produced in] the twelfth month.

div.note: On the ingredients necessary to make *jiō/* [*Rehmannia glutinosa/*] infusion
div.p:
On the ingredients necessary to make *jiō/* [*Rehmannia glutinosa/*] infusion
Twenty *koku/* of *kijiō/* 〈ten *koku/* presented by Izumi Province, ten *koku/* obtained from the physic garden [attached to the Bureau of Medications];〉 one* jō/* and two *shaku/* of silk floss; six *shaku/* of coarse plain silk to strain the infusion; six sheets of coarse plain silk to cover the jars 〈each one *shaku/* in length and nine *sun/* in width;〉 one bowl; one sheet of coarse plain silk to cover the bowl 〈length one *shaku/*, width nine *sun/*;〉 one *ton/* and a half of silk to cover the mouth of the cauldron; two *tan/* and four *jō/* of cloth collected as tax-in-kind to squeeze the *jiō/*; three *ton/* of silk floss; one *tan/* of tradable cloth; three *jō/* of cloth collected as tax-in-kind to cover the *yuka/* jar 〈each four *shaku/* in length, two times the standard width〉 twenty *kin/* of ropes for the lathe made with boiled hemp fiber 〈in case of damage, request a replacement;〉 five *jō/* of clean aprons made of cloth collected as tax-in-kind 〈six *shaku/* each;〉 five sets of outer work garment 〈six *shaku/* each;〉 one piece of towel 〈length five *shaku/*;〉 six *shō/* of oil for torches; three half-dried gourds to be used as ladles to pour the infusion [of *jiō/*]; two draining baskets [to filter scum]; six *yuka/* jar where to store the fluid extracted [from the *jiō/*]; sixteen Sue ware jars where to store the *jiō/* infusion 〈each to receive more than five *shō/*;〉 six *tataibe/* pots where to pour the fluid extracted [from the *jiō/*]; one Sue ware bowl where to pour a sample of infusion [of *jiō/*] 〈also add a plate;〉 three large containers; three ladles; sixteen sheets of paper 〈as material to cover the mouth of the jars [in which the *jiō/* infusion will be stored];〉 one large *kin/* of mulberry bark strings to tie and secure the mouth of the jars; 2,400 *kin/* of firewood; twenty *koku/* of new charcoal.
div.note: "Tradable cloth" translates *shōfu/* 商布, namely textiles (as a rule, other than silk; e.g., hemp) that, instead of being used as tribute or tax-in-kind, could be used for trade.

This is usually described as a jar-like vessel with a large mouth used for offerings during ceremonies; see, for instance, Arai Hideki. "Engi Shukeishiki no doki ni tsuite (jō)," pp. 80-81. That, however, does not seem to be its use here, since in this passage we are told that *yuka/* are to be used to store the fluid extracted from the *jiō/*.

*No/* 幅 (also read *haba/*) in the text. Different types of cloth (e.g., *chōfu/*, *yōfu/*) had different standard widths, and the *no/* value refers to the standard width for the type of cloth in question.
div.p: Provide three high officials [in the Bureau of Medications], four royal physicians 〈as for the aforesaid officials, increase or decrease their number depending on the circumstances〉 and three minor functionaries with one *jō/* of coarse plain silk and two *ton/* of silk floss each as pure clothes. Provide ten apprentices of medications and two palanquin bearers [in charge of carrying the *jiō/*] with two *jō/* and seven *shaku/* of cloth collected as tax-in-kind each 〈upper garment, two *jō/*; *hakama/* trousers, seven *shaku/*.〉

As for the aforesaid miscellaneous items, submit an application to the Ministry of Royal Affairs on the first day of the ninth month and receive them. However, if there is a variation in the amount of *jiō/*, also adjust the number of miscellaneous items to request based on that. During the period of production of the infusion, supply [those involved in its production] with *sake/* and food for no more than sixteen days.

div.note: [On the offering of *shōbu/* and *namakomo/* on the fifth day of the fifth month]
div.p: [On the occasion of the seasonal celebrations at court] on the fifth day of the fifth month, in order to present *shōbu/* and *namakomo/* [non desiccated *Zizania latifolia/*/wild rice] 〈members of the Bureau will prepare these〉 arrange four tables made of unbarked lumber 〈two tables are to be used for the offering to the *tennō/*, and two tables are for the distribution to court officials. The Bureau will prepare them all;〉 six *ryō/* of *karamushi/* [*Boehmeria nivea/*/ramie]; and four *kin/* of *tsuzura/* [*Sinomenium acutum/*/Asian moonseed] 〈request these to the Ministry of the Royal Household.〉 All those in the Ministry of the Royal Household with a rank lower than deputy director, and those in the Bureau of Medications with a rank lower than head will carry these together, will enter the venue in question and present them. Once done, they will take their leave. The deputy director [of the Ministry of the Royal Household] will remain and report [to the *tennō/*] 〈as for the words to be pronounced here, refer to the protocols for the Ministry of the Royal Household.〉 For the royal consort and the heir apparent, utilize two tables of unbarked lumber each 〈one for the royal consort and the heir apparent, one for the distribution to court officials.〉
div.note: The fifth day of the fifth month was of the five main seasonal festivals (*gosekku/* 五節句) that were, on the basis of Chinese models, celebrated at the Japanese court as early as in the eighth century. *Shōbu/*, also known as*ayamegusa/*, played an important role within the celebrations held on this day, because of its apotropaic associations that were already established in China and mentioned in numerous ancient texts; for some examples, see Moriya Mitsuo 守屋美都雄 et al, eds. *Keiso saijiki/* 荊楚歳時記. Heibonsha, 1978, p. 146. *Shōbu/* could be pulverized and mixed in *sake/* (as described in the *Jingchu Suishiji/*), used in decorations, or worn on one's person. In the *Engi shiki/*, it is not specified how the *shōbu/* offered in this context would be then used.
[On the *kōji/* mold and *ōgon/* to be used in the production of medications]
div.p: Every year obtain from the Ministry of the Royal Household the wheat to be used as material to make *kōji/* for the production of medications 〈two *to/* as material for the royal medications [for the *tennō/*], eight *to/* as material for miscellaneous medications to be distributed as remuneration to court officials;〉 and seven *to/* of glutinous rice to be used to steam and desiccate fifty *kin/* of *ōgon/*.
div.note: Read "*kamutachi/* 加無太知" in the *Wamyō ruiju shō/* 和名類聚抄 (scroll 4 of the ten-scroll version); another reading given there is "*kiku/* 菊." It was most likely used to ferment rice in order to make *sake/* for medicinal use.
[On the offering of *goshuyu/* on the ninth day of the ninth month]
div.p: [On the occasion of the seasonal celebration at court] on the ninth day of the ninth month, hand over twenty bunches of *goshuyu/* to the [inner palace's] Office of Medications and have them present it [to the *tennō/*].
div.note: Another of the five main seasonal festivals celebrated at the Japanese court. On this occasion, *goshuyu/*, another plant with apotropaic associations, was used in decorations or worn on one's person. This use dates back to ancient China and can be seen, as in *shōbu/*'s case, already in the *Jingchu Suishiji/* 荊楚歳時記.
[On the offering of milk]
div.p: Present to the *tennō/* three large *shō/*, one *gō/* and five *shaku/* per day. For the materials needed for the production of one year [of milk]: three *jō/* and one *shaku/* of silk floss 〈use them [to make] twenty-one sieves, eight of them, one *shaku/* and six *sun/* each in size; and [the other] thirteen, one *shaku/* and four *sun/* each in size;〉 four *jō/* and two *shaku/* of red silk; four *jō/* and two *shaku/* of green silk to be used at the back 〈both to be used as materials to cover two tables; length seven *shaku/*, three times the standard width each;〉 two *jō/* and four *shaku/* of cloth collected as tax-in-kind 〈to be used to cover the tables on rainy days; each six *shaku/* in length, two *no/*;〉 three *hiki/* of acorn-color silk from the eastern provinces 〈to be used for the clothes of the three men who will carry the tables, one *hiki/* for each person;〉 five *tan/*, two *jō/* and five *shaku/* of bleached hemp cloth 〈three *jō/* and three *shaku/* for the men [who will carry the tables], respectively four *shaku/* each as fabric for their sashes and seven *shaku/* for their *hakama/* trousers; three *tan/* and three *shaku/* for the three men who will milk the cows, respectively three *jō/* and six *shaku/* as fabric for their pure unlined kimonos, and seven *shaku/* for their *hakama/* trousers; one *tan/*, three *jō/* and one *shaku/* for the three men who will carry the tables, respectively four *shaku/* each as fabric for two short-sleeved kimonos, five *shaku/* each for two pieces of outer work garment; as fabric for three pieces of cloth to wipe the Sue ware bowls, three *shaku/* each; as fabric for two sieves to cut water, four *shaku/* each; as fabric for two headgears, three *shaku/* each; as fabric for two towels, three *shaku/* each; one *jō/* as fabric for a cloth to restrain the cows' legs; seven *shaku/* as fabric to wrap around the cows' abdomen; as fabric for three cloths to wipe milk, three *shaku/* each;〉 five *ryō/* of silk thread 〈to sew the sieves and the clothes and *hakama/* trousers for the men [who will carry the tables];〉 five bowls of Sue ware; jars and flat flasks, two each; Sue ware *tataibe/* pots, container, *sarake/* pot and washing basin, one each; two tall stands; two plain wood chests; one stand to be used to carry loads; two wooden lids 〈all to be used to collect milk;〉 one barrel 〈to store the rice and soy bean gruel used as cow fodder;〉 one *shō/* of oil 〈to be used on the last day of the twelfth month;〉 one hundred and fifty *kin/* of firewood per day 〈in order to cook the rice gruel for the cows;〉 one *to/* and four *shō/* per day of rice and soy beans to be used as cow fodder for the seven dairy cows 〈one *shō/* for each cow.〉 As for the above, request and receive them every month from the Ministry of the Royal Household.
div.note: A *sarake/* pot was a relatively flat, big-mouthed vessel. Smaller than a *kame/* pot, it was used to store fluids: in the *Engi shiki/*, it is used to store *sake/*, but also water, oil and milk. See Arai Hideki 荒井秀規. "Engi Shukeishiki no doki ni tsuite (jō)," pp. 79-80.
[On the dairy cows]
div.p: As yearly fodder for the seven dairy cows and the seven calves, 4,434 *kin/* of dried grass will be needed. 〈Yamashiro Province will provide 2,332 *kin/* as cultivated fodder and 500 *kin/* as gathered fodder; Naniwa Province will provide 1,603 *kin/* as cultivated fodder.〉
div.note: Southern part of present-day Kyoto Prefecture.
On the materials necessary for the production of the royal medications
div.p:
On the materials necessary for the production of the royal medications
Two *koku/* of sesame [*Sesamum indicum/*] 〈to be made into a paste;〉 one *to/* of fermented beans 〈to be used in the production of miscellaneous medications;〉 two *to/* of foxtail millet [*Castanea crenata/*] 〈to be used to bring water to boil;〉 three *to/* of salt 〈to be used to boil water and steam-iron;〉 one piece of curtains made of cloth collected as tax-in-kind 〈length seven *shaku/*, three *no/*;〉 one plain wood chest; one mortar 〈also attach a pestle;〉 720 *kin/* of firewood.
As for the aforesaid, request all items from sesame to salt every year in the twelfth month from the Ministry of Royal Household. However, as for the curtains, the plain wood chest and the mortar, only request a new one in case of damage [to the ones currently in use].

div.note: On the materials for the production of *hafuni/* (white [face] powder) for the *tennō/*
div.p:
On the materials for the production of *hafuni/* (white [face] powder) for the *tennō/*
One *koku/* and five *to/* of glutinous rice; one *koku/* of foxtail millet 〈request them from the Office of the Court Ladies;〉 two *jō/* of silk floss as fabric for sixteen pouches made from lined silk cloths 〈for the *tennō/* and for his consort;〉 two *jō/* of silk floss to be used as fabric for four pieces of curtains to desiccate the white [face] powder; four silk sieves 〈five *shaku/* each;〉 two *tan/* of cloth collected as tax-in-kind 〈to be used for the four curtains. Two *jō/* each;〉 three *ryō/* of silk thread to sew; forty sheets of wrapping paper; four plain wood chests; four large containers for water 〈capacity of above five *to/*;〉 three ladles; two bamboo mats; two long straw mats 〈as seats for the women's physicians;〉 four containers; four sake barrels; two stands to carry loads 〈as for the three items above, only request a replacement in case of damage [to the ones currently in use].〉 The fourteen women's physicians that will assist [in the operations above] will receive one *shō/* of steamed rice, one *shaku/* of salt, one *gō/* of *hishio/* with lees and three *gō/* of sake per day per person. Supply the aforesaid for no longer than thirty days.
div.note: The curtains are meant, presumably, to prevent wind and rain from coming in.

In the text, *kasu hishio/*, namely *hishio/* from which *kasu/* (lees) have not been filtered out. This suggests that this *kasu hishio/* would have been closer to the miso currently produced in Japan in terms of texture, while *hishio/* was more liquid. *Hishio/* was a fermented condiment made from grains, soybeans and *kōji/*. See the "Royal Meal Protocols" for more details on its culinary uses.
[On royal processions]
div.p: On the occasion of royal processions, one high-ranking official and one royal physician [from the Bureau of Medications] will, at the head of four apprentices of medications, carry the medications [for the *tennō/*] and accompany him. If the royal procession includes an overnight stop, they will, at the head of apprentices of *i/*[*jutsu/*], have them carry one *tan/* of crude medicinal herbs, various texts of prescriptions and materials [necessary for the compounding of medications]. 〈As for the types of medications and materials, they will be decided depending on the circumstances. 〉 As for the carriers, request them to the Ministry of the Royal Household. In addition, for the attires and the provisions for the provincial corvée laborers and the carriers, likewise submit a request to the Ministry of the Royal Household.
div.note: *Jikichō/* 直丁. Under the *ritsuryō/* system, men in good health between 21 and 60 years of age were sent by the provinces to serve in the capital for three years at a rate of two persons per fifty households. Of these two men, who were known as *jichō/* 仕丁 (this term appears in art. 16), one would actual perform physical labor and was known as *jikichō/*; the other man would aid the *jikichō/* in his daily life.
[On the escort for the Daijōe]
div.p: Those who will escort the *tennō/* on the occasion of the procession to perform his ablutions for the Daijō-e as part of the enthronement rituals, namely one assigned official from the Bureau of Medications and one royal physician, will be provided with an attire of a color appropriate to their rank 〈for those of the fifth and sixth rank, follow their respective colors.〉 The two apprentices of medications will each be given a crimson unlined kimono woven with fine thread, white *hakama/* trousers and a non-silk sash; the two provincial corvée laborers will each be given a yellow unlined kimono made of cloth collected as tax-in-kind, white *hakama/* trousers and a non-silk sash; the two provincial corvée helpers will be given two indigo non-silk unlined kimono, two pairs of white hemp *hakama/* trousers and two hemp sashes. As for all the above, request them to the Ministry of the Royal Household and collect them from the Ministry of Great Storehouse.
div.note: Now most commonly called Daijōsai, it is the first Niinamesai 新嘗祭 (Great Harvest Rite) carried out by a *tennō/* after their enthronement. The sovereign makes offerings from the provinces to the *kami/* Amaterasu, and then consumes a meal in her company.
[On the royal princess serving at the Ise Shrine]
div.p: On the occasion of the departure of the royal princess designated to serve at the Grand Shrine [of Ise], hand over twelve doses of medications to the person in charge of escorting her off 〈seven-*qi/* pellets, *goshuyu/* pellets, *shakuyaku/* pellets, four-flavor *richū/* pellets, *kankyō/* pellets, Liaodong pellets, two doses each.〉 On the types of medicinal herbs to use, consult books of prescriptions. As for other necessary items: six *shaku/* and five *sun/* of oiled cloth to wrap the medications; eighteen sheets of paper; five *ryō/* of mulberry bark strings; four *shaku/* of silk as fabric for two sieves; two *shaku/* of silk gauze as fabric for one loose sieve; two *shō/* of rice vinegar; one small *oribitsu/* container to store the medications; twelve men to crush [the medicinal herbs] 〈each man will pound one dose per day;〉 two *to/* and four *shō/* of rice 〈two *shō/* per person per day;〉 two *gō/* and four *shaku/* of salt 〈two *shaku/* per person per day.〉
div.note: A royal princess was designated to serve at the Ise shrines and officiate rituals for the *kami/* there enshrined on behalf of the *tennō/*. Before moving to Ise to take her post, she would, however, first have to undergo a period of purificatory abstentions at Nonomiya, located in the Sagano area, in the north-western outskirts of the capital. At the end of this period of ritual purification, she would be ready to be escorted to Ise, in modern-day Mie Prefecture.

Maruyama Yumiko surmises that this medication, which makes its only appearance here, corresponds to a formulation found in the classical book of recipes compiled by the famed Chinese scholar Sun Simiao, the *Qianjinfang/* 千金方 (Recipes worth a thousand [pieces of] gold). What makes this identification plausible is that these Liaodong pellets were in that text used in case of menstrual irregularities, which is a possibility in the case of the royal princesses discussed in this article. Maruyama. "Hochū," p. 1035.

div.note: This line, which is present in the original text, covers the content of articles 18 to 25, and includes stock of medications that had to be prepared for specific bureaus and offices.
Twenty-five types for the Bureau of Skilled Artisans
div.p:
Twenty-five types for the Bureau of Skilled Artisans
One *kin/* and two *ryō/* each of *saishin/* and *byakujutsu/*; fourteen *ryō/* of *kikyō/*; one *kin/* of *bushi/*; three *ryō/* each of *rojo/*, *hange/*, *byakuren/*, *shōriku/*, *hōsō/*, *saiko/*, *botan/*, *chiyu/*, *uzu/*, *daigeki/* and *genjin/*; ten *ryō/* of *shokushō/*; seven *ryō/* of *daiō/*; two *shō/* of *goshuyu/*; four *ryō/* each of *bukuryō/*, *shion/*, *tōki/* and *kyūkyū/*; six *ryō/* of *byakushi/*; two *shō/* of peach kernels; one *ryō/* of gypsum.

div.note: Forty types for the Bureau of Carpentry

div.note: *Kyōkechi/* 夾纈 is an ancient method to decorate textiles already established by the Nara period. A cloth was firmly pressed between two wooden boards onto which a pattern had been carved. While dyeing techniques involving the use of wooden boards are still used in Japan today, *kyōkechi/* fell into disuse by the Kamakura period; for this reason, the specifics about this decorative and dyeing technique are unknown.

*Hō/* 袍 is the outer garment of a formal ceremonial court outfit. It is characterized by a round neck and wide sleeves. It is still worn by members of the Japanese imperial family on some ritual occasions.
[On the study of books of prescriptions]
div.p: In learning books of prescriptions, the following time limits will apply: 460 days for the *Classic of the Grand Basis/*; 310 days for *Newly compiled materia medica/*; 310 days for *Small Essays/*; 200 days for *Hall of Light/*; sixty days for the *Classic of the eighty-one difficult issues/*. As for the instructors [of the Bureau of Medications], reserve them the same treatment as those in the Bureau of Great Learning, and supply them with food and *sake/*, combustible oil and monetary rewards.
div.note: This is short for *Inner Canon of the Yellow Emperor: Grand Basis/* (Ch: *Huangdi neijing Taisu/* 黄帝内経太素), one of the four texts known under the title of "Inner Canon of the Yellow Emperor." *Taisu/* was compiled in the eighth century by Yang Shangshan as an annotated revision and combination of *Suwen/* 素問 (Basic Questions) and *Lingshu/* 霊樞 (Numinous pivot). However, unlike the other two texts, which remained popular throughout Chinese history, *Taisu/* fell into obscurity and was eventually lost in China; it survives only partially in manuscripts dating back to the twelfth century kept at Ninnaji, an important temple in Kyoto, and the Kyōu shooku 杏雨書屋 archive in Osaka.

*Xinxiu bencao/* 新修本草. A revision and expansion of Tao Hongjing's the *Bencao jing jizhu/* 本草経集注 (Collected commentaries on the Classic of *Materia Medica/*), it was drafted by a committee of 22 members chaired by Su Gong and completed in 659. While the *materia medica/* textbook established under the *ritsuryō/* system was the *Bencao jing jizhu/*, already in an entry recorded in *Shoku Nihongi/*, the second official history of Japan, dating to 787 (Enryaku 6), we read that the Bureau of Medications petitioned the court to have the textbook concerning *materia medica/* changed to the more recent and more extensive *Xinxiu bencao/*, and that this petition was granted. The *Engi shiki/* reflects this change. See Maruyama. "Hochū," p. 1038.

*Xiaopin/* 小品 (also *Xiaopin fang/*; "prescriptions from the small essays"). A book of prescriptions compiled in the fifth century by Chen Yanzhi. While it exists today only in a largely fragmentary fashion, it was in the past a highly valued texts on medicinal recipes. It was one of the required textbooks for Tang court physicians, and it enjoyed the same position within the *ritsuryō/* system in Japan. It is also very extensively quoted in *Ishinpō/*, the tenth-century compendium of continental therapeutic and diagnostic modalities compiled by Tanba no Yasuyori.

*Ming Tang/* 明堂. Text associated with the *Huangdi neijing/* corpus. It was compiled by Yang Shangshan, who also compiled *Taisu/*, and focused on acumoxa. It faded into obscurity and was long believed lost, but sections of it have been found in Japan in the archives of the Sonkeikaku-bunko 尊経閣文庫 library in Tokyo, and of the Buddhist temple Ninnaji in Kyoto. *Ming Tang/* was one of the required textbooks for students of *i/*[*jutsu/*] and needles already in the *Ishitsuryō/* (Regulations on healing and disease) section of the *ritsuryō/* codes.
*Nan jing/* 難経. A pre-Tang text (possibly compiled as early as the first or second century CE) that, as per title, discusses 81 issues in question-answer form, with a focus on pulse and acumoxa.
[On the classification of the books of prescriptions]
div.p: Classify the *Canon of Yellow Emperor: Grand Basis/* as a large book; the *Newly compiled materia medica/* as a medium book; the *Small Essays/*, the *Hall of Light/*, and the *Classic of the eighty-one difficult issues/* as short books.
div.note: While textbooks for the Bureau of Great Learning had already been classified in a similar fashion in the *Gakuryō/* 学令 (Regulations on learning), this was not the case for the texts required for officials in the Bureau of Medications. Large, medium and short refers, quite intuitively, to the size of the texts in question. While both *Newly compiled materia medica/* and *Small Essays/* had to be mastered within 310 days (see previous article), the former was classified as "medium," the latter as "short." Maruyama. "Hochū," p. 1039.
[On the seats to be used during lectures]
div.p: As materials to be used to make seats for the lectures [on the books of prescriptions], two cushions made out of woven wild-rice leaf mats 〈for the instructor of *i/*[*jutsu/*] and the instructor of needles;〉 three long straw mats 〈for the apprentices.〉 Request and receive them every three years from the Ministry of the Royal Household.

div.note: [On the treatment of exceptionally accomplished apprentices]
div.p: Provide the four exceptionally accomplished apprentices [in the Bureau] with food and clothing in the same amount as that of the exceptionally accomplished apprentices in the Bureau of Great Learning.

div.note: [On the salary of provincial physicians]
div.p: With respect to the salary of provincial physicians, every year deduct one tenth of that amount per person and exchange that amount with products from that province that can easily be transported. Have them carried to the capital by the envoys in charge of carrying tributes presented as tax-in-kind. In case of nonpayment, inform the Bureau of Accounting and prevent the issue of a receipt to the envoys. However, this provision will not apply in case of concurrent appointment as royal physician or instructor of *i/*[*jutsu/*] and needles [and provincial physician], and in case of provincial physicians hired without going through the established procedures.

div.note: [On the payment of teachers by the provinces]
div.p: With respect to the products that provinces will send as payment for the teachers, inspect them and store them in the warehouse of the Bureau. The products paid on behalf of those who were apprentices of *i/*[*jutsu/*] and needles will be assigned to their respective instructors [*hakase/*], and the products paid on behalf of those who were apprentices of medications will be assigned to the royal physicians.

div.note: [On the medicinal herbs for those of the fifth rank or above]

div.note: [On the pasture of Ajihara]
div.p: The pasture of Ajihara is assigned to the Bureau as a pasture for its dairy cows. If bulls are born, they will be employed for plowing the physic garden, or for breeding.

div.note: [On the skin of cows that perished in the pasture of Ajihara]
div.p: With respect to the skins of the cows perished in the pasture of Ajihara, sell them and allocate the proceeds to repairs of the facilities of the Bureau of Medications. However, include the profit from that sale in the end-of-year ledger and submit it to the Council of State.

div.p: As for [the provisions] listed above, have them carried [to the capital] by the envoys in charge of carrying tributes presented as tax-in-kind, and sent to the Bureau. Once [the Bureau] has inspected and stored them, release a receipt. Regarding Dazaifu, entrust [its provisions] to the envoys for additional tributes.
div.note: This expression refers to articles 45 to 98.

Provinces in the Saikaidō did not submit tax payments directly to the capital; instead, these were sent to Dazaifu and used to sustain its operations. For this reason, there were no envoys in charge of carrying tributes presented as tax-in-kind from the Saikaidō provinces to the capital. Dazaifu's provisions for the Bureau of Medications were, therefore, entrusted to envoys in charge of transporting additional tribute (*bekkō/* 別貢), a form of tax imposed on all provinces (including Dazaifu) except the five Kinai provinces and Shima, to the capital.
